entry.title: 埃丝特·克劳福德 (Esther Crawford) 在推特上，马斯克之前和之后
entry.content:
埃丝特·克劳福德（Esther Crawford）（之前在这里提到过，她在推特上吹嘘自己在工作中睡觉是为了赶上不必要的最后期限），写了一篇精彩的文章，讲述了她在公司的经历，包括马斯克收购前后的情况。

虽然我对埃隆了解不多，但我持谨慎乐观的态度——我认为他是建立了特斯拉和 SpaceX 等令人难以置信且持久的公司的人，所以也许他的私人所有权可以改变现状，为公司注入新的活力。

克劳福德在公司内部，而我则远离公司，但这正是我对马斯克领导下的 Twitter 持乐观态度的原因。 Twitter 几年前（也许是十年前）就已经僵化了，需要进行彻底的重组，但要针对公司的文化和产品。虽然我认为马斯克领导下的 Twitter 现在情况要糟糕得多，但他绝对确实改变了一切，如今类似 Twitter 的服务的整体状况比以前要好得多。在马斯克收购 Twitter 之前，Mastodon 是无关紧要的。否则，11 月之后的增长就不会出现。我现在乐观地看好 Threads，而且我认为，如果不是马斯克收购并摧毁了 Twitter，Threads 甚至不会存在。

我认为这是一个敏锐的洞察力：

埃隆在解决基于物理的难题方面拥有非凡的天赋，但促进人与人之间的联系和沟通的产品需要不同类型的社交情感智能。

另一种思考这个问题的方式（我抄袭了 Ben Thompson 本周在Dithering上所说的话）并不是马斯克缺乏同理心，而只是软件本身的本质。不变的物理定律以不适用于软件的方式抵制马斯克的不合理要求。他似乎不听不同意他观点的人的意见，但当物理学不同意时他必须倾听。 （今天早些时候关于特斯拉伪造续航里程估计的故事纯粹是由软件决定的。）

软件比硬件需要更多的创造性纪律，因为如此多的纪律已经融入到创建硬件的本质中。硬件向人们灌输纪律；人们必须向软件灌输纪律。

如果我没有注意到，在所有这一切中，还有一个对任何取得成功的人的警示故事，那就是我的失职——那就是，你爬得越高，你的世界就会变得越小。这是一个奇怪的悖论，但最富有和最有权势的人也是最孤立的人。

我发现自己经常看着埃隆，看到一个看起来很孤独的人，因为他的时间和精力完全投入到工作中，这不是我想要的生活模式。

查尔斯·福斯特·马斯克 (Charles Foster Musk) 嘟哝着“X”而不是“Rosebud”。

★

entry.title: “我们不能只是继续分发水”
entry.content:
本杰明·韦尔蒙德 (Benjamin Wermund) 和贾尔·罗梅罗 (Jhair Romero) 为《休斯顿纪事报》报道（新闻+链接）：

几名移民要求喝水，但被警察拒绝，他们说没有，尽管沿河的许多类似军事的哨所都备有瓶装水。

奥利瓦雷斯当天早些时候表示，士兵们被告知在决定分发饮用水时要运用自己的判断力和自由裁量权。他说，每天有 600 至 1,000 人过境，州政府无法为每个人提供一瓶。

奥利瓦雷斯说：“如果他们看到儿童或成人看起来患有某种中暑衰竭，他们就会给他们喝水。” “但我们不能只是继续分发水，因为将会发生的情况是，你将继续鼓励他们来。”

这就是你知道德克萨斯州州长格雷格·阿博特是个白痴的原因——这段话的残酷程度是超乎想象的。我们在这里谈论的是酷热条件下的水。 （亚当·艾萨克森评论道：“就好像在热浪中给寻求庇护者提供水就像给海鸥提供面包​​一样。简直令人难以置信。”）

entry.title: 特斯拉夸大的续航里程估计
entry.content:
Steve Stecklow 和 Norihiko Shirouzu，路透社报道：

特斯拉几年前就开始通过操纵其里程估算软件来夸大其车辆的潜在行驶距离。据一位熟悉该软件早期设计的人士透露，大约十年前，出于营销目的，该公司决定为其测距仪编写算法，向驾驶员显示充满电池后可以行驶的距离的“乐观”预测。其仪表板读数。

这位人士表示，然后，当电池电量低于最大电量的 50% 时，该算法将为驾驶员显示更真实的剩余行驶里程预测。消息人士称，为了防止驾驶员因预计行驶里程开始更快下降而陷入困境，特斯拉设计了“安全缓冲区”，即使在仪表板读数显示电池电量耗尽后，也可以增加约 15 英里（24 公里）的行驶里程。

这位人士表示，提出乐观范围估计的指令来自特斯拉首席执行官埃隆·马斯克(Elon Musk)。 “埃隆希望在充满电后显示出良好的续航里程数，”该人士说道，并补充道：“当你从停车场购买一辆汽车时，看到续航里程为 350 英里、400 英里，这会让你感觉很好。”

这不是“每个人都这样做”的情况：

汽车网站 Edmunds.com 的车辆测试总监 Jonathan Elfalan 在对特斯拉以及福特、通用汽车、现代和保时捷等其他主要汽车制造商的车辆进行了广泛检查后，得出了与 Pannone 类似的结论。该网站于 2021 年 2 月报道，Edmunds 测试的所有五款特斯拉车型均未能达到其宣传的续航里程。其他制造商的其他 10 款车型中，除了一款之外，其他车型均超出了其宣传的续航里程。

开始与马斯克这个家伙建立联系。

entry.title: 仁慈是智慧的象征
entry.content:
伊利诺伊州州长 JB Pritzker 在西北大学毕业典礼上的演讲片段对我来说非常真实。随着年龄的增长，我的想法也越来越遵循同样的思路。整个剪辑值得一看，但重点是：

发现白痴的最好方法是什么？寻找残忍的人。当我们看到某人长得不像我们、听起来不像我们、行为不像我们、爱不像我们、生活不像我们时，几乎每个人的第一个想法要么源于恐惧，要么源于判断，或两者兼而有之。这就是进化。作为一个物种，我们通过对不熟悉的事物保持怀疑而生存下来。

为了变得友善，我们必须关闭动物本能，迫使我们的大脑走上不同的道路。同理心和同情心是进化的存在状态。它们需要心理能力来超越我们最原始的冲动。我来这里是想告诉你们，当一个人在这个世界上的道路上充满了残酷行为时，他们就没有通过先进社会的第一次考验。他们从不强迫自己的动物大脑进化超越其第一本能。他们从未建立新的心理途径来克服自己本能的恐惧。因此，他们的思维和解决问题的能力将缺乏最善良的人所拥有的想象力和创造力。

在我多年的政界和商界生涯中，我发现一件事是普遍正确的：房间里最善良的人往往是最聪明的。

我喜欢用“白痴”来回应残酷行为的想法。

entry.title: 你永远猜不到 Twitter 对拥有 @x 账号的人做了什么（剧透：你会猜到）
entry.content:
萨拉·佩雷斯 (Sarah Perez) 为 TechCrunch 撰文：

@x Twitter 账号的所有者证实，该公司（现在称为 X）在没有警告或经济补偿的情况下接管了他的帐户，并告诉他该账号是 X 的财产。该账号之前属于企业摄影的Gene X Hwang和摄像工作室Orange Photography 。在一封信中，该公司（前身为 Twitter）感谢黄先生的忠诚，并为他提供了精选的 X 商品和参观 X 总部的机会，以“表达我们的谢意”。

无论如何，X Corp 都会获得@x 句柄。但毫不奇怪，这是一种非常糟糕的方法。感谢黄先生以良好的精神接受这一切。 （帐户的新句柄： @x12345678998765 。）

★

今天早上，X Corp 名义首席执行官 Linda Yaccarino 发送了全公司范围的备忘录：

大家好，

多么重要的周末啊。

每个人都对我说：“琳达，你在想什么？你不想为那个人工作。他很疯狂，也很冲动。你在 NBC 找到了一份很棒的工作。你有一个美好的未来。如果你接受这份工作，你的职业生涯将会陷入困境，你的名字也会成为笑点。 “我有听他们的话吗？

正如我昨天所说，无论是在生活中还是在商业中，你有机会给人留下深刻的印象是极其罕见的。这就是我们一起实时经历的事情。花点时间来正确看待这一切。

白天喝是可以的。我是。

17 年前，Twitter 给世界留下了持久的印记。该平台改变了人们访问信息的速度。它为人们如何沟通、辩论和应对世界上发生的事情创造了新的动力。 Twitter 为人们、公众人物和品牌提供了一种建立持久关系的新方式。无论如何，这里的每个人都是这一变革的驱动力。但同样，我们所有的用户和合作伙伴都不断地挑战我们，让我们有更大的梦想，更快地创新，并发挥我们的巨大潜力。

Twitter 是一个具有深远影响的简单概念。

通过 X，我们将进一步改造全球城镇广场，并再次给世界留下深刻印象。

不只是你。我也不知道发生了什么事。

我们公司拥有独特的动力来实现这一目标。

该死的埃隆。

许多公司表示他们希望快速发展，但我们喜欢以光速发展，当我们这样做时，那就是 X。

根据爱因斯坦的狭义相对论，当物体接近光速时，物体的质量变得无穷大，移动它所需的能量也变得无穷大。但这对于所有运动中的物体来说都是正确的，而狭义相对论的一个令人费解的方面是，物体运动得越快，它经历时间的速度就越慢。如果你能够以光速移动，时间就根本不会过去。这就像永远被诅咒一样，永远陷入当下，而世界却在为其他人而继续前进。

我想这个。

我们的核心是发明家心态——不断学习、测试新方法、做出改变以使其正确并最终取得成功。

我们的现金正在大量流失，而我们的广告商却仍在逃离。

通过X，我们通过不懈地努力维护自由表达和选择、创造无限的互动性并创建一个能够使所有参与者获得经济成功的市场，为整个用户和客户社区提供服务。

我曾经为 NBCUniversal 投放所有广告。现在，我正在运行一个每月 8 美元的多层次营销计划，唯一注册的用户是拥有 MAGA 帽子系列的男性。

最好的消息是我们进展顺利。

没有希望。

每个人都应该为过去九个月的创新步伐感到自豪——从长篇内容到创作者货币化，以及品牌安全保护方面的巨大进步。

您看到我们这些天投放的广告了吗？上周，我们在每个人的时间轴上都贴满了打折咀嚼丸的广告，广告的妙语是，你会用力地操你的女人，然后她需要助行器的帮助。这是我们向大家宣传的视频。本周是恋足癖者的动漫。这就是我们在每个人的动态中每三条推文中放入的内容。或者X，或者无论我们现在如何称呼它们。我曾经与可口可乐和宝洁等公司签订了价值数亿美元的奥运会赞助协议。 （感谢上帝赐予苹果。）

我们的使用率处于历史最高水平

我们的主人像风筝一样高高在上。

我们将继续为整个社区提供音频、视频、消息、支付、银行业务方面的新体验，为创意、商品、服务和机会创建一个全球市场。

我们的焦点小组测试表明，虽然银行业对信任这个平台的兴趣（让我们面对现实，该平台并不以其可靠性而闻名），但正如您所期望的那样，整体而言相当低，但在银行业中却出人意料地高。知道卡图德是谁的人。

请不要认为这一刻是理所当然的。

请退出。出去。我求求你。离开时你可以写上你在“Twitter”工作的简历。

你们正在书写历史，而我们的转变是没有限制的。

似乎这场品牌重塑灾难还不够，我们的基础设施正在崩溃。 Facebook 在不到一周的时间内将 Threads 的用户数量从 0 顺利增加到 1 亿，同时我们对使用率施加了滑稽的限制。我的意思是你能相信这种狗屎吗？我还是不行。我对他说：“埃隆，我们是一家以广告为基础的企业。我们的收入与使用量直接成正比。这就像经营赌场并关闭老虎机以节省电费一样。这个不成立。”埃隆就像“机器人！”

邀请所有人与我们一起构建 X。

我想我曾经在电视节目中看到，一名人质能够通过在句子中随机放置逗号来向当局发出需要帮助的信号，而无需惊动绑架者。

Elon 和我将与每个团队和合作伙伴合作，将 X 推向世界。这包括让我们整个社区了解最新情况，确保我们所有人都拥有前进所需的信息。

我在周六午夜和你一起发现了这个改名的消息，我不知道那个混蛋接下来要做什么，也不知道他什么时候会这么做。你知道这个。你知道我知道你知道这一点。但我会坚持认为这些决定是由我领导的团队做出的，因为否则会更加丢脸。

现在，让我们一起给世界留下下一个深刻的印象。

琳达

我很抱歉。

琳达

entry.title: ★ X Corp 首席执行官 Linda Yaccarino 的全公司备忘录从人质代码翻译成英文
苹果的 MLS 交易似乎进展顺利
entry.content:
John Ourand 和 Alex Silverman，《体育商业杂志》的报道：

上周，当苹果公司的埃迪·库伊在华盛顿特区向满屋子的美国职业足球大联盟老板和高管发表讲话时，他回想起一年前他与联盟官员的谈话，当时苹果公司正在与联盟媒体签署一份为期 10 年的协议。权利。

当时，库伊回忆说，上周三，当几位美国职业足球大联盟老板和联盟高管找到他，询问球队可以做些什么来帮助确保这项开创性的交易取得成功时，库伊给出了同样的回应——签下优秀的球员。

就在世界上最伟大的足球运动员莱昂内尔·梅西 (Lionel Messi) 首次代表迈阿密国际俱乐部亮相的几天前，库伊在美国职业足球大联盟 (MLS) 董事会上发表讲话，他微笑着对美国职业足球大联盟 (MLS) 老板和官员们说：“孩子，你们做到了。”

梅西周五的处子秀非常戏剧化——加时赛中的一记制胜任意球。如果你把它放进电影剧本里，人们会翻白眼。

美国职业足球大联盟季票订阅者的数量是一个严格保守的秘密。单场比赛的收视率数据从未公开分享。多位高层俱乐部业务主管表示，[苹果公司，原文如此]要求他们签署保密协议，以便了解与 MLS 季票订户数量有关的任何数据。 [...]

消息人士称，MLS 季票订阅者已接近 100 万，其中包括购买季票时获得访问权限的季票持有者。 6月初，这些消息来源称美国职业足球大联盟(MLS)季票订户基数为70万，联盟高管认为这显示出良好的增长势头，他们预计一旦梅西开始比赛，这一数字还会进一步膨胀。

传统电视广播和流媒体之间的显着区别之一——不仅是体育赛事，而是所有领域——是传统电视的收视率是公开的。网络吹嘘高收视率。对于流媒体来说，收视率是一个严格保守的秘密。 MLS 季票的订阅者数量是否准确？ 100 万？只有苹果知道。这是一个好数字吗？这很难说，因为 NFL、NBA 和 MLB 也对其同等订阅套餐的数量保密。

entry.title: 疫苗问世后，共和党各县的新冠死亡率更高
entry.content:
Jacob Wallace、Paul Goldsmith-Pinkham 和 Jason L. Schwartz 在《JAMA Internal Medicine》上发表的一篇论文《佛罗里达州和俄亥俄州共和党和民主党登记选民在 COVID-19 大流行期间的死亡率过高》中表示：

2018年1月1日至2021年12月31日期间，俄亥俄州和佛罗里达州的研究样本中有538,159人死亡年龄为25岁或以上。死亡中位年龄为 78 岁（IQR，71-89 岁）。总体而言，共和党选民的超额死亡率比民主党选民的超额死亡率高出 2.8 个百分点，即 15%（95% 预测区间 [PI]，1.6-3.7 个百分点）。 2021 年 5 月 1 日之后，当所有成年人都能接种疫苗后，共和党和民主党选民之间的超额死亡率差距从 -0.9 个百分点（95% PI，-2.5 至 0.3 个百分点）扩大到 7.7 个百分点（95% PI） ，6.0-9.3个百分点）在调整后的分析中；共和党选民的超额死亡率比民主党选民的超额死亡率高出43%。在疫苗接种率较低的县，共和党和民主党选民之间的超额死亡率差距更大，这一差距主要体现在居住在俄亥俄州的选民中。

这项研究强烈表明，与新冠病毒死亡率相关的唯一因素是疫苗接种。此外，新冠肺炎是一种主要导致老年人死亡的疾病——这项研究中的超额死亡率全部发生在 75 岁及以上的人群中。即使在 65-74 岁的人群中，超额死亡率也有所下降。在疫苗问世之前，倾向共和党和倾向民主党的县之间的所有其他政策差异并未导致死亡率出现差异。

我不知道如何解释只有俄亥俄州而非佛罗里达州出现超额死亡率这一事实。这项研究本身似乎并没有为这种差异提供假设。也许是天气？俄亥俄州的老年人在室内呆的时间更多，而那里的新冠病毒传播可能性更大？

这位去年收购了 Twitter 的科技亿万富翁在其网站上将社交平台重新命名为 X.com，并开始用拉丁字母表第 24 个字母的程式化版本取代鸟标志。据《纽约时报》看到的照片显示，在 Twitter 位于旧金山的总部内，自助餐厅里投射了 X 标志，而会议室也被重新命名为带有 X 的单词，包括“eXposure”、“eXult”和“s3Xy”。

这就是为什么特斯拉的车辆型号为 S、3、X 和 Y，并在公司网站上按此顺序列出。它就像联邦快递标志中的箭头，但适用于 12 岁的男孩。

马斯克早就表示他可能会更名，但他在周日早些时候的一条推文中加快了这一进程，他宣称“很快我们将告别 Twitter 品牌，并逐渐告别所有鸟类。”他曾表示，希望将 Twitter 打造成一款名为 X 的“一切应用程序”，不仅涵盖社交网络，还涵盖银行和购物。

周一早些时候，马斯克还分享了一张 Twitter 旧金山办公楼上投影的巨型 X 的照片，并配文：“今晚是我们的总部。”

我讨厌*说“我早就告诉过你了”，但我早在 5 月 1 日就预测到了这一确切的名称变更。正如我在几周后重申这一预测时所写的：

事实上，他现在主要将其称为“这个平台”，这让我认为他会尽快将其重命名为“X”。不过，在我看来，抛弃 Twitter 品牌名称似乎很疯狂，所以也许“X”对于 Twitter 来说就像“Meta”对于 Facebook 和“Alphabet”对于 Google 一样。但同时：马斯克也做了一些疯狂的事情。扔掉整个 Twitter 品牌不会比他一开始就买下它那么疯狂。

《泰晤士报》的这篇文章引用了一位品牌专家的话说，显而易见的是，品牌名称的动词非常罕见，而且非常有价值。当人们在 Twitter 上发帖时，他们就是在发推文。他们发的推文就是推文。每个人，甚至是从未使用过 Twitter 的人，都知道tweet 的含义。现在马斯克认为它们会被称为“x”？

尽管事实上马斯克几个月来显然一直在朝着更名的方向努力——如果不是从他提议购买该公司之前开始的话——这一转变完全是（但可以预见的）草率。马斯克声称是“临时”的新徽标只是Unicode 字符“𝕏” （U+1D54F，数学双连大写 X ）。该公司今天试图更换旧金山总部的标牌，但由于对该公司是否拥有工作许可证感到困惑，工作被迫停止，标牌仅被部分拆除。 iOS和Android应用程序都没有更新，甚至该公司的网站上几乎到处都写着“Twitter”。

entry.summary: 检查 Microsoft 新的默认字体 Aptos 和其他四种新的 Office 字体。
entry.content:
Si Daniels，Microsoft Office 设计字体和排版首席项目经理（我的天啊，微软的人都有很长的头衔吗），上周在 Medium 上发表了一篇备受关注的文章， 1 “ 字体的变化：微软新的默认字体已经到来”：

亲爱的地球上每一个曾经输入过文字的人，

我知道这只是一个轻松的问候，但让“每个人”看到 Office 默认字体的并不是文本的输入，而是文本的阅读。除了 Excel 之外，我从未经常使用过任何 Office 应用程序，那是 20 多年前的事了。但无论您个人是否使用 Office，都不可能不遇到使用 Office 创建的文档。因此，微软的排版选择影响着我们所有人。 （例如，我从未在 Arial 中设置过任何内容，但由于它的普遍存在，它几乎每天都会令人烦恼。）

15 年来，我们心爱的 Calibri 一直是 Microsoft 的默认字体和办公通信的皇冠守护者，但如您所知，我们的关系已经自然结束。我们改变了。我们每天使用的技术已经发生了变化。因此，我们开始寻找适合更高分辨率屏幕的完美字体。 The font needed to have sharpness, uniformity, and be great for display type. It was exciting at times, but also intimidating. How do you replace Calibri? How do you find that one true font that can take its place as the rightful default?

As we shared before, Microsoft commissioned five new fonts: Bierstadt, Grandview, Seaford, Skeena, and Tenorite. It was our hope that one of them would be our next default font for Microsoft 365. All of them were added to the drop-down font picker. From there, as you got a chance to use them, we listened to your impassioned feedback and chose the one that resonated most which was Bierstadt. But as there was a change of guard so too the name. Bierstadt is now known as Aptos.

I don't know if Microsoft actually chose Aptos (née Bierstadt) based on customer feedback, but it says a lot about the company either way. Companies that have taste do not conduct design via surveys. (My guess is they're full of shit and probably knew all along they were going to go with Aptos/Bierstadt, the obvious choice , from the start. The “survey”, such that it was, seemingly consisted of just reading people's replies on Twitter .)

What I find weird about the whole thing is that Microsoft still hasn't really shown any of these new fonts. They've provided glimpses of them, but mostly at large display sizes, not text sizes, which is where they really matter in the context of Office documents. I'm not the only one to find this curious .

So I took matters into my own hands, and created rudimentary specimens for each of Microsoft's five new typefaces (and Calibri to boot). A–Z in upper- and lowercase, 0–9, and the most common punctuation marks. Then a paragraph of sample text at 11 points. Dear reader, you really owe me for this one, because I had to use the web app version of Word, by way of Microsoft 365 2 to produce these PDFs. To describe this software as brutal and frustrating is an understatement. Herewith, the PDF specimens, and my brief comments:

  • Aptos — Designed by Steve Matteson . I don't know why Microsoft states as fact that Calibri somehow needed to be replaced as their default font just because it's 15 years old. A good default font should stand the test of time for decades, if not a literal lifetime. 3 But if Microsoft feels the need to chase fleeting fashion rather than timeless style, Aptos is the trendiest of the bunch: grotesque sans serifs are having a moment. Aptos is by no means a rip-off of Apple's San Francisco , but it is, by far, the most San-Francisco-esque of any of these typefaces.值得注意的人物：J（发育不良且丑陋）、Q（小尾巴）、R（受Univers启发？）、g（双层，让人想起富兰克林哥特式）和数字1（弯曲的帽子， a la , of所有字体，Arial）。 But the most distinctive character is the lowercase L, which has a curve to differentiate it from the uppercase i and numeral 1.

  • Grandview — Designer Aaron Bell admits Grandview was largely inspired by DIN, and it certainly looks like it. Far too mechanical to serve as the default font. For chrissake look at those quotation marks and apostrophes.

  • Seaford — Designed by Tobias Frere-Jones, Nina Stössinger, and Fred Shallcrass . Seaford strikes me as the only other font in the bunch that might conceivably have been chosen as the new default. If Microsoft had better (any?) taste, they would have chosen Seaford. Seaford strikes my eye as most similar to Martin Majoor's rightfully renowned and beloved Scala Sans , with — maybe — a wee dose of influence from, of all typefaces, Frere-Jones's ex-partner Jonathan Hoefler's aptly-named Ideal Sans . 4

  • Skeena — Designed by John Hudson and Paul Hanslow . Looks like it came off a clip art CD circa 1995.

  • Tenorite — Designed by Erin McLaughlin and Wei Huang . Admittedly inspired by Adrian Frutiger's hall-of-fame typeface Avenir , and looks like it. Too friendly, bordering on childish (see the single-story lowercase “a”), to serve as the default for Office.

  • Calibri — Designed by Lucas de Groot . It's not my bag, personally, 5 but Calibri is both a very good sans serif and a fine default for Office. There's no reason Microsoft couldn't have stuck with Calibri for decades to come.

Here's a zip archive of all 6 specimens , if you'd prefer to download them all.

Original Postscript

The kerning is rather awful in all of these PDF specimens, at times jarringly so. I suspect, or at least hope, the problem is with the web version of Word (which I presume has its own text rendering engine), not the fonts themselves. Look, for example, at the words milliner and Uncle (which looks like “Unde” in some of them) in the sample text. If these fonts were available for download, I'd have typeset the specimens using better software, but they're not, so I can't. I suppose I could fish out the web fonts used by Microsoft 365, but this whole endeavor has consumed enough of my time as it is.

New Postscript, Updated 22 July

The kerning problem with the original PDFs I produced was indeed, ultimately, caused by the fact that I was using the web version of Microsoft Word. Friend of the show Glenn Fleishman used the native Mac version of Word to produce new PDFs from my Word documents, and the kerning problems are gone. All of the above links now go the updated PDFs. (And of course Glenn, of all people, cared enough to lend a hand.) If you're curious, and I suppose I would be if I were you, here's an archive of the original PDFs with the perverse kerning.

Apple Tries to Explain to UK Legislators That You Can't Add Back Doors to Secure Protocols
entry.content:
Zoe Kleinman, reporting for BBC News:

Apple says it will remove services such as FaceTime and iMessage from the UK rather than weaken security if new proposals are made law and acted upon.

The government is seeking to update the Investigatory Powers Act (IPA) 2016. It wants messaging services to clear security features with the Home Office before releasing them to customers. The act lets the Home Office demand security features are disabled, without telling the public. Under the update, this would have to be immediate. [...]

WhatsApp and Signal are among the platforms to have opposed a clause in the Online Safety Bill allowing the communications regulator to require companies to install technology to scan for child-abuse material in encrypted messaging apps and other services. They will not comply with it, they say, with Signal threatening to “walk” from the UK.

The BBC headline here is fair: “Apple Slams UK Surveillance-Bill Proposals”. Techmeme's rewrite of the headline is not: “Apple Threatens to Remove Services Like FaceTime and iMessage From the UK Rather Than Weaken Their Security Under a Proposed Investigatory Powers Act Amendment”. Usually this works the other way around — Techmeme typically rewrites headlines to add clarity and omit clickbait-yness. But Apple (and Signal, and WhatsApp) aren't making threats here. They're patiently explaining that E2EE messaging platforms cannot comply with what the UK wants to demand. It'd be like trying to comply with a law that declares 1 + 1 = 3.

The UK legislators pushing this believe, wrongly, that it must be possible for these messaging platforms to add “good guys only” back doors. That if they pass this law, the result will be that the nerds who work at these companies will be forced to figure out a way to comply. What will actually happen is that these companies will be forced to pull the services from UK, because they can't comply, unless they scrap their current end-to-end encryption and replace it — worldwide — with something insecure, which they aren't going to do.

The UK, of course, is no longer part of the EU, but the unintended consequences are similar: the intention of the EU's Digital Markets Act (well, one intention among many) is to force big social networks to collect data in ways that are more respectful of users' privacy. The actual result is that Threads launched everywhere else in the world but the EU. The intention of the UK's proposed update to the IPA is to force messaging platforms to make profound technical changes that would allow law enforcement to snoop on messages; the actual result, if it goes into effect, will be to force those messaging platforms out of the UK.

And while it's Apple and iMessage/FaceTime that are getting the headlines today, it's WhatsApp that's the big player in the UK , with 75 percent of adult Britons using it monthly. It's hard to overstate how much outrage these legislators are poised to bring upon themselves if they effectively ban WhatsApp. (The legislators themselves surely all depend upon it.)

entry.title: Kevin Mitnick Dies From Pancreatic Cancer at 59
entry.content:
Tragic news from King David Memorial Chapel and Cemetery in Las Vegas:

Kevin David Mitnick, 59, died peacefully on Sunday, July 16, 2023, after valiantly battling pancreatic cancer for more than a year. Kevin is survived by his beloved wife, Kimberley Mitnick, who remained by his side throughout their 14-month ordeal. Kimberley is pregnant with their first child. Kevin was ecstatic about this new chapter in his and Kimberley's life together, which has now been sadly cut short.

All cancers can go fuck themselves, but man, pancreatic cancer has taken so many people of late: Alex Trebek, Pixar animator Ralph Eggleston , Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and of course Steve Jobs. Also: Jef Raskin and Randy Pausch (“ The Last Lecture ” professor).

Just brutal to hear that Mitnick's wife is pregnant.

Kevin emerged from his final prison term, which he deemed a “vacation”, in January 2000. He was a changed individual, and began constructing a new career, as a White Hat hacker and security consultant. He became a highly sought-after global public speaker, a writer, and established the successful Mitnick Security Consulting. In November 2011, he became the Chief Hacking Officer and part owner of security awareness training company KnowBe4, founded by close friend and business partner Stu Sjouwerman.

Kevin attracted attention and support from unlikely sources. The bus driver who saw young Kevin memorize the bus schedules, punch cards and punch tool systems so he could ride the buses all day for free testified as a character witness for Kevin during his federal trial. The federal prosecutor offered his testimony that Kevin never tried to take one dime from any of his “victims”. The probation officer assigned to monitor Kevin after prison gave Kevin permission to write his first book on a laptop when he was not yet supposed to have access to computers. Shawn Nunley, the star witness in the FBI's case against Kevin, became so disillusioned with the government's treatment of Kevin that he contacted Kevin's defense team, helped garner Kevin's release, and became one of Kevin's dearest friends. Kevin had an irresistible way of converting foes to friends and keeping them as friends forever.

Mitnick was technically gifted, but his greatest hacking skill was social engineering.

entry.summary: Once you view Bloomberg's original reporting through this prism — that most of their original reporting is delivered with the goal of moving the stock prices of the companies they're reporting on, for the purpose of proving the value of a Bloomberg Terminal's hefty subscription fee to day-trading gamblers — a lot of their seemingly inexplicable stylistic quirks don't seem so inexplicable any more.
entry.content:
Mark Gurman, reporting for Bloomberg, “ Apple Tests 'Apple GPT,' Develops Generative AI Tools to Catch OpenAI ”:

The iPhone maker has built its own framework to create large language models — the AI-based systems at the heart of new offerings like ChatGPT and Google's Bard — according to people with knowledge of the efforts. With that foundation, known as “Ajax”, Apple also has created a chatbot service that some engineers call “Apple GPT”.

In recent months, the AI push has become a major effort for Apple, with several teams collaborating on the project, said the people, who asked not to be identified because the matter is private. The work includes trying to address potential privacy concerns related to the technology.

It's not surprising that Apple has a project like this underway. It would be rather shocking if they didn't. And it shouldn't be surprising that Apple is a latecomer to shipping software that exposes AI chatbot-type features. Apple is seldom first to adopt new technology, especially something with the privacy ramifications of AI chat.

I was banging this drum before WWDC, but one app that needs this sort of functionality is Xcode. Xcode is the only major developer IDE I'm aware of that doesn't offer AI code generation and analysis. I've seen some demos from readers who use Microsoft's VS Code and they're amazing.

Next paragraph:

Apple shares gained as much as 2.3% to a record high of $198.23 after Bloomberg reported on the AI effort Wednesday, rebounding from earlier losses. Microsoft Corp., OpenAI's partner and main backer, slipped about 1% on the news.

If you ever notice, Bloomberg news stories always contain updates like this. It's an obsession unique to Bloomberg. My understanding is that this decade-old Business Insider story remains true : Bloomberg reporters are evaluated and receive bonuses tied to reporting market-moving news. They're incentivized financially to make mountains out of molehills, and craters out of divots, to maximize the immediate effect of their reporting on stock prices. And Bloomberg appends these stock price movements right there in their reports, to drive home the notion that Bloomberg publishes market-moving news, so maybe you too should spend over $2,000 per month on a Bloomberg Terminal so that you can receive news reports from Bloomberg minutes before the general public, and buy, sell, and short stocks based on that news. No other news organization I'm aware of has an incentive system like this for reporters — but no other news organization has a business like the Bloomberg Terminal.

Here's the graph of Apple's share price today . Gurman's report was published at 12:03pm, and boom, Apple's stock price jumped at exactly 12:04pm. It then mostly came back down to where it was, presumably after everyone realized there really wasn't any news here other than the fact that Apple is working on something we all presumed they were working on. Apple's stock finished up 0.7 percent for the day.

Microsoft's stock graph for today doesn't show as dramatic a downward spike as Apple's jump, but they were trading at $359.35 at 12:01, and dropped to $356.84 at exactly 12:04, one minute after Gurman's report hit Bloomberg Terminals. The “ this is bad news for Microsoft ” line of thinking, presumably, is that if OpenAI has a long-term moat around LLM AI technology, Microsoft is likely to acquire them or otherwise maintain their position as an exclusive partner, and Apple might eventually need to pay through the nose to license OpenAI/Microsoft technology. But if there is no moat , and even Apple is developing its own LLM systems, then maybe Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI isn't worth much long-term.

Apple's brief 2.7 percent jump and Microsoft's smaller but still-significant drop, both at 12:04pm, were clearly caused by Gurman's report. Bloomberg Terminal subscribers get such reports before anyone else. (Bloomberg employees, of course, know such information before it's published, but I'm sure never do anything untoward with it.) Once you view Bloomberg's original reporting through this prism — that most of their original reporting is delivered with the goal of moving the stock prices of the companies they're reporting on, for the purpose of proving the value of a Bloomberg Terminal's hefty subscription fee 1 to day-trading gamblers — a lot of their seemingly inexplicable stylistic quirks don't seem so inexplicable any more. They just seem a little gross.

  1. According to Wikipedia , “the Bloomberg Terminal is available for an annual fee of around $24k per user or $27k per year for subscribers that use only one terminal. As of 2022, there were 325,000 Bloomberg Terminal subscribers worldwide.” That's about $8 billion per year in revenue. ↩︎

entry.summary: Two ways to automatically relaunch an app that's crashing in the background.
entry.content:
Item 1: Dropbox remains an excellent service, seemingly utterly reliable, with fair pricing.

Item 2: Dropbox's official Mac client has been a confusing, ugly, resource-heavy mess for years, and is only getting worse.

Item 3: Maestral is an open source Dropbox client for MacOS and Linux, developed by Sam Schott. It provides exactly what I want in a Mac Dropbox client, and what the official Dropbox app once was , long ago: a folder that syncs, with a minimal user interface that lives in a menu bar app. It uses far less memory than Dropbox's official client and offers a much simpler interface.

I switched from Dropbox's official Mac client to Maestral last August. Overall I've been very happy with the move. But Maestral is not for everyone. From Maestral's website, under “Limitations” :

Currently, Maestral does not support Dropbox Paper, the management of Dropbox teams and the management of shared folder settings. If you need any of this functionality, please use the Dropbox website or the official client.

Maestral uses the public Dropbox API which, unlike the official client, does not support transferring only those parts of a file which changed (“binary diff”). Maestral may therefore use more bandwidth that the official client. However, it will avoid uploading or downloading a file if it already exists with the same content locally or in the cloud.

I don't use Dropbox Paper, don't have a Dropbox “team”, and I'm fine going to the Dropbox website to manage shared folder settings. The only thing I miss from the official Dropbox client is the Finder contextual menu item to copy a sharing link to an item — but I need that seldom enough that I don't much mind doing that on the Dropbox website too.

Another big difference: the official Dropbox client is transitioning to MacOS's relatively new File Provider APIs .这些 API 允许基于云的存储提供商仅在线保存某些文件，仅在需要时将文件下载到本地。我不需要也不想要那个。 I just want my entire Dropbox folder's contents to sync entirely. （Maestral 确实支持 Dropbox 的“选择性同步”来省略指定的文件夹和文件，但这些省略的文件根本不会显示在本地文件夹中。）如果您将 Dropbox 文件夹保留在外部硬盘驱动器上，则可能需要切换到 Maestral，因为 Apple 的文件提供程序 API 要求将文件夹存储在~/Library/CloudStorage/中。借助 Maestral，您的本地 Dropbox 文件夹可以位于任何地方。

Bottom line: 11 months in, and I'm a very happy Maestral user.

但。在过去一个月左右的时间里，我注意到每当我唤醒我的 Mac（运行 MacOS Ventura 13.4.1 的 M1 MacBook Pro）时，Maestral（版本 1.7.3）就不再运行。 It crashes silently in the background while my Mac is sleeping (or when waking up?).这是在 GitHub 上针对该错误提交的问题，六位用户也提出了同样的意见。显而易见的创可贴解决方案是每次唤醒 Mac 时手动重新启动 Maestral，但这很烦人且容易忘记。 The whole point of Dropbox is that it just works in the background, automatically.

在等待 Maestral 本身修复时，这里有两个解决方法。 They should be applicable in any situation where you want to automatically relaunch an app that is periodically crashing in the background.

Workaround 1: LaunchControl and launchd

launchd is Apple's longstanding (dating back to Mac OS X 10.4) system for running background processes, either on a schedule or triggered by events.管理launchd作业的内置方法是launchctl命令行实用程序。 1 launchd is very nerdy and has a ton of features .

Enter Robby Pählig's LaunchControl : “a fully-featured launchd GUI allowing you to create, manage and debug system and user services on your Mac.” It costs $21 for a personal license and is worth every cent. LaunchControl is well-designed, comprehensive, and extensively-documented.

In my case, I wanted to create a new launchd job that will keep Maestral running at all times.当我的 Mac 睡眠时崩溃时，我只想让它静静地重新启动。 Creating such a job using LaunchControl is trivial.

首先，将 Maestral 应用程序拖放到 LaunchControl 应用程序图标上。 This will show a dialog box like this:

Click “For current user”. 2

就是这样。 This does exactly what we want by default: it creates a new user-only launchd job that keeps Maestral alive no matter what.如果崩溃了，它将重新启动。如果我们手动退出 Maestral，它将重新启动。

One bit of manual fiddling I suggest is giving the job a descriptive name. By default, LaunchControl just names it “local.job”. I renamed mine “local.Maestral.keepalive”:

此作业的文件（重命名后）位于~/Library/LaunchAgents/local.Maestral.keepalive.plist 。但如果您使用 LaunchControl，则永远不需要处理该文件。 If you ever want to trash it (eg after a version of Maestral ships with a fix for this bug), you can do so within LaunchControl itself.

Workaround 2: Keyboard Maestro and AppleScript

For anyone else out there running into this bug with Maestral 1.7.3, the LaunchControl/ launchd solution described above is all you need for a workaround.但我内心的书呆子想知道 Maestral 在后台崩溃的频率。当 Maestral 在我的 Mac 睡眠时崩溃时，它似乎不会留下任何类型的日志来描述发生了什么或何时发生。

So here's another workaround, this time using Keyboard Maestro and a tiny AppleScript.首先，在 Keyboard Maestro 中创建一个新的全局宏。我将我的名字命名为“Maestral：Keep Alive”。 Set it up like this:

触发器是“登录时定期”，每分钟运行一次，全天运行一次，一周中的每一天运行一次。 The action is this simple AppleScript:

 if application "Maestral" is not running then display notification (current date) as string ¬ with title "Maestral was not running" do shell script "/usr/bin/open /Applications/Maestral.app" end if

If Maestral is running when this script runs, nothing happens.如果不是，脚本会显示一条包含当前日期和时间的通知，然后启动 Maestral。 Sometimes I notice the notification appear after I wake my Mac, sometimes I don't. But I can go to Notification Center and see the whole stack of them to see how often it's occurring. (Turns out it gets triggered a dozen or so times overnight, every day.)

Astute scripters might wonder why I'm using do shell script "/usr/bin/open /Applications/Maestral.app" to launch Maestral, instead of the idiomatic tell application "Maestral" to launch .好问题。 The answer is that each time Keyboard Maestro runs this AppleScript, it needs to be compiled. And whenever an AppleScript is compiled, any applications targeted by tell blocks will be launched if they aren't already running.这只是 AppleScript 工作方式的一个怪癖，但在这种特殊情况下，它会破坏脚本的整个目的，因为当脚本运行时，Maestral 将始终运行，因为如果它在宏开始执行之前尚未运行，它将在 Keyboard Maestro 编译脚本时启动，这发生在脚本实际运行之前。因此，我们使用一行 shell 脚本重新启动 Maestral。

  1. The standard POSIX cron utility is still supported on MacOS, but is deprecated in favor of launchd . ↩︎

  2. Which, to be a HIG pedant, ought to be title-cased : “For Current User”. ↩︎︎

entry.content:

entry.summary: Alas, this situation has become a recurring theme. Now it's Apollo, the exquisitely well-made Reddit client by Christian Selig.
entry.content:
When Twitter unceremoniously pulled the plug on third-party clients earlier this year, commercial Twitter clients like Tweetbot and Twitterrific were left in a perilous position. I wrote :

Twitter's kneecapping of third-party clients didn't just mean that their future revenue was gone — it meant revenue they'd already collected from App Store subscriptions would need to go back to customers in the form of prorated refunds for the remaining months on each and every user's annual subscriptions. Consider the gut punch of losing your job — you stop earning income. It's brutal. Now imagine that the way it worked when you get fired or laid off is that you're also suddenly on the hook to pay back the last, say, 6 months of your income. That's where Tapbots and The Iconfactory are.

I can't recall a situation like this, with an ecosystem of third-party clients collecting subscriptions and then having the first-party service yank the carpet out from under them — and their customers — with zero warning or sunset period.

Alas, this situation has become a recurring theme. Now it's Apollo , the exquisitely well-made Reddit client by Christian Selig. The situation is nearly identical: Apollo stopped working earlier this week, and Selig is on the hook for hundreds of thousands of dollars in refunds to annual subscribers.

Just as with Tweetbot and Twitterrific, if you're a subscriber to Apollo, here's what you can do to support Selig:

  1. Reinstall Apollo if you've already deleted it; otherwise, make sure you're running the latest version.
  2. Tap the “I Don't Need a Refund” button.
  3. Feel good and go buy yourself a treat, knowing you helped a talented developer (and nice person).

Here's Selig, in his goodbye post on the Apollo subreddit :

It feels disingenuous on the surface to say “I want to thank all of you”, but in this case it's demonstrably true. I've worked on this app for over 9 years, and I've never felt burned out, I get such a crazy amount of energy and enjoyment out of building something so publicly alongside such an awesome community, and you seriously have no idea how easy product development is when your north star is just “listen to what people are saying”. [...]

I'm really heartbroken with how this whole process unfolded, I truly drank the Kool Aid talking to Reddit at the beginning that this was something they were going into in good faith with the interest of developers, moderators, and the community as a whole, but as many people pointed out to me, it's clear now that ultimately wasn't their intent. If they wanted something that could work for everyone, they would have simply made an effort to listen, instead of being dishonest, callous, and punitive in pricing. I'm sorry to all the folks who, like me, lost Apollo abruptly as a result of this. I had so much more I wanted to do with this app!

But, legitimately, I really feel a sense of that “Don't cry because it's over, smile because it happened” right now. I grew up so much developing Apollo, I met and learned from so many incredible people, made lifelong friends, got to go to multiple WWDCs and was even featured in a few, and I got to work on a product and platform I absolutely loved for 9 years. That's an incredible run, and it's hard to feel anything but thankful for that.

In addition to the “I Don't Need a Refund” button, the final release of Apollo has a bunch of bonus content, including a few dozen wallpapers and some treats for Selig's other app, Pixel Pals . I find Selig's good spirits in the face of this debacle to be inspiring. (See also: Selig's recent appearance on The Talk Show .)

entry.summary: Some initial thoughts and observations on Facebook's much-anticipated Twitter rival.
entry.content:
Facebook's much-anticipated Twitter rival Threads — branded “an Instagram app” — is out. Some initial thoughts and observations:

  • The website's home page contains just a link to the apps for iPhone and Android, but you can view the profile pages for users and permalinks for posts (threads?).

  • The iOS app only supports an iPhone layout. I suppose I should not find this surprising, given that 13 years after launching, Instagram's iOS app still doesn't support the iPad natively, but somehow I do find this surprising. What a fucking mystery for the ages it is that Instagram won't make iPad apps.

  • They're going with the “www” prefix on the web, just like Instagram. That feels archaic to me.

  • The website is view-only. You can't log in, post, or reply. No indication whether this is temporary or by design.

  • URLs are similar to Instagram's: domain name + “/t/” + unique post ID. (Where Threads uses a “/t/” (for threads ), Instagram uses a “/p/” (for post , I presume.) For example: https://www.threads.net/t/CuRtcYTNY3J/ . Much better would be a URL format that includes the username of the poster, so you can tell who posted it just by looking at the URL. Example URLs that show attribution:

    Twitter: https://twitter.com/daringfireball/status/1667603292162240512
    Bluesky: https://bsky.app/profile/gruber.foo/post/3jznmowkftf2e
    Mastodon: https://mastodon.social/@daringfireball/110652280163526529

  • Signing in was incredibly easy using my existing Instagram credentials, which were already on my phone because I have Instagram installed. I didn't even need to re-enter my password. Same username, same avatar, and I opted in to following the exact same accounts on Threads that I follow on Instagram.

  • The timeline is algorithmic — it shows you threads both from people you follow and from people you don't. Just after Threads went live to the public, my timeline was almost entirely from accounts I don't follow, seemingly users who've been testing Threads while it was in beta. As I type this sentence a few hours later, however, my timeline is mostly from people I follow, and thus much more enjoyable. But as yet, there's no way to filter your timeline to only show threads from accounts you've chosen to follow.

  • You can search for accounts, but there's no content search (yet?).

  • No hashtags (yet?) either . Good riddance, I say , but I'll bet they're forthcoming.

  • One feature Threads has launched with, though, are quote posts (retweets in Twitter parlance). Bluesky has them too. Quote posts are useful, fun, and central to the way many people use Twitter. And Mastodon doesn't have them — not by omission, but by design. As I've quipped , Bluesky feels like a new service for people who liked what Twitter used to be. Threads feels like that too. Mastodon feels like a service for people who hated Twitter, and nothing exemplifies that more than its lack of quote posting.

  • Posts are limited to 500 characters, which I think is the upper bound for a Twitter-like service.

  • No word about an API yet. I'm not suggesting that Threads might offer an API to enable third-party clients — no way Facebook would do that — but there ought to be a programmatic interface for bots and such if they want to eclipse Twitter. ( Which Zuckerberg is already stating as a goal .)

  • Speaking of Zuck, in addition to being quite active on Threads out of the gate, he posted to Twitter for the first time in 11 years, and it's perfect .

  • Over 5 million people signed up for Threads in the first 4 hours after launch. (There are about 1.2 million active Mastodon users .)

  • No ads yet. If Threads is successful, surely there will be ads. But in the meantime, it makes for a much better experience than Twitter, where the ads are frequent, large, and scammy . (And they soon might start playing sound .)

  • The site/app seems a bit slow/flaky at the moment, but overall is holding up, and still seems faster than Mastodon.

  • Threads is available in over 100 countries, but not yet in the EU, thanks to their draconian and confusing Digital Markets Act . Rather than forcing US and Asian companies to comply with their regulations, the EU seems more likely to be isolating its citizens from the broader world.

  • ActivityPub federation isn't supported yet but is forthcoming. Instagram chief Adam Mosseri posted :

    We're committed to building support for ActivityPub, the protocol behind Mastodon, into this app. We weren't able to finish it for launch given a number of complications that come along with a decentralized network, but it's coming.

    If you're wondering why this matters, here's a reason: you may one day end up leaving Threads, or, hopefully not, end up de-platformed. If that ever happens, you should be able to take your audience with you to another server. Being open can enable that.

I Like Threads's Chances

The overall vibe of Threads is probably not for me. It's not frantic, but it is busy, and very pop-culture-y. If you're the sort of person who wants a quiet timeline comprised only of posts from carefully curated accounts, Threads is not for you, and probably never will be. But the sort of people who like Twitter's “For You” feed and trending topics in the sidebar might find Threads more fun.

So I'm bullish on Threads's chances for long-term success:

  1. The world needs, or at least wants, something like Twitter.
  2. Twitter itself is falling apart under Musk.
  3. Mastodon is inherently too confusing for mass market adoption, and in ways that can't be fixed without some central authority coming in and imposing a solution, which is against the fediverse's ethos. That doesn't mean Mastodon is doomed or bad. Just that it's never going to achieve mainstream popularity.
  4. Bluesky — which is the one I'm rooting for, personally — remains invitation-only as they scale and continue to define their underlying protocol.
  5. All the other Twitter-like upstarts like Post and T2 and whoever else have no traction at all.
  6. Threads starts with 1 billion eligible users, who already have their usernames, and can opt into following the exact same people they follow in Instagram, which is a product that continues to thrive and which people enjoy.
  7. Facebook and Instagram know how to operate at the highest possible scales — both technically and regarding content moderation. Instagram's content moderation record is far from perfect, but content moderation at scale is impossible to do perfectly . Facebook does it better than anyone, and much better than Twitter.

I even like the name “Threads” — it's short, easy to spell, memorable, makes for a clever icon/logo , and even starts with a “T”, reminding people of Twitter. The word tweet has been a nice thing for Twitter to have stumbled onto. (They didn't coin it; Twitterrific did .) Tweet works both as a noun and verb and everyone in the world knows what it means, whether they use Twitter or not. I don't think thread is going to take off as a verb for Threads, but it's a great noun for posts, and it reinforces the notion that you're supposed to engage with posts by replying.

Elsewhere

Casey Newton has an interview with Mosseri at Platformer. Regarding the EU, Mosseri said:

The more pressing concern at the moment is to launch Threads in all the countries where Meta wants to. It won't be available in the European Union to launch as Meta works to ensure that Threads complies with the EU's new data privacy regulations.

“That's just going to take a while, unfortunately — and I'm particularly frustrated about this point, because I've been living outside of the US for a year now,” said Mosseri, who has been working from London. “I've been on a total kick with my teams about stop launching things in only a couple countries, and not in other countries. … But in this case, it was either we wait on the EU, or delay the launch by many, many, many months. And I was worried that our window would close, because timing is important.”

Regarding the opportunity for Threads, as Twitter self destructs, Newton writes:

When the competition is an app where “cisgender” is considered a slur , Threads has an easy time standing out as an oasis of calm and civility.

Mosseri also granted an interview to Alex Heath at The Verge , where he had a thoughtful answer to the question of why Threads is a standalone app:

It was a hugely contentious debate internally. You could be in feed. You could be a separate tab. You could be a separate app. The challenge with text posts in feed is that the post and comment model just fundamentally does not support public discourse as well as the model that Twitter pioneered with tweets and replies. Treating replies as equal as opposed to subordinate somehow just allows for a very different and much more broad range of public conversations. People do post text to Instagram all the time, even though we don't support it first class, and we're experimenting with that, too. That's great, but I think it solves a much smaller use case than public discourse more broadly.

Then there's a separate app versus separate tab. Separate tab is tough. There's only so much stuff you can shove in the app. It's already feeling too complicated. We're trying to actually simplify right now, and so it's certainly working against that. And generally, when you build a separate tab, you find you want to push all that distribution through a feed invariably in order to bootstrap it. You kind of end up right back in that first problem.

A separate app is way less likely to succeed because you have to bootstrap a user base from very little or from nothing. But if you do it, if you succeed, the upside is so much more significant.
